title: Boxing Day Shopping is Getting Quieter
summary: Boxing Day shopping in the UK is not as busy as it used to be. Many people are choosing to shop online instead of going to stores. Data shows that visits to high streets and shopping centers are down compared to last year. Shoppers are expected to spend less money overall, even though some plan to spend a bit more. People are being careful with their money because of costs. Some big stores like Next and John Lewis closed on Boxing Day. Shoppers say it feels calmer and more enjoyable now. Experts think this change is because people are nervous about spending money, especially after tax announcements.

background_read: Boxing Day is a holiday in the UK on December 26th, known for big sales in stores. Traditionally, people would go out to shop for bargains, but now many prefer to shop online from home. This change is part of a bigger trend where shopping habits are shifting due to technology and money concerns. Understanding this helps see how holidays and spending are changing over time.
Article_Structure: WHO: Shoppers in the UK and experts like Karen Johnson and Diane Wehrle
WHAT: Boxing Day shopping is becoming quieter with fewer store visits and less spending
WHERE: In the UK, including high streets, shopping centers, and online
WHY: Because people are shopping online more and being cost-conscious due to economic worries

perspectives.description: Some shoppers enjoy the calmer atmosphere and find it more pleasant to shop on Boxing Day now.
Experts say people are nervous about spending money because of costs and tax changes, leading to less shopping.
